description:
Populus alba x Populus glandulosa is a naturally occurring hybrid between the white poplar (Populus alba) and the glandular poplar (Populus glandulosa). This hybrid is known as the silver poplar or the hybrid poplar.

The silver poplar is a deciduous tree that can grow up to 30 meters tall. It has a broad, rounded crown and a straight, cylindrical trunk. The leaves are lobed and have a distinctive silvery-white underside due to the dense covering of tiny, white hairs. This leaf characteristic is inherited from the white poplar parent.

The bark of the silver poplar is smooth and grayish-white, becoming fissured and darker with age. The tree produces catkins, which are the characteristic flowers of poplars, in early spring before the leaves emerge.

The silver poplar is a fast-growing tree that is adaptable to a wide range of soil conditions, including poor, dry, or wet soils. It is commonly used in landscaping and urban forestry due to its ornamental features and ability to tolerate a variety of environmental stresses.

The hybrid nature of Populus alba x Populus glandulosa combines the characteristics of both parent species, resulting in a tree that displays a unique combination of traits that may be desirable for certain applications or environmental conditions.
